meanings.definition: To convert or be converted into carbon.
meanings.sent1: After the fire, the wood began to carbonize and turn into charcoal.
meanings.sent2: The scientist studied how different materials carbonize when exposed to high temperatures.
meanings.sent3: The chef accidentally left the bread in the oven too long, causing it to carbonize and become inedible.
meanings.sent4: The intense heat of the sun seemed to slowly carbonize the plastic toys left outside.
meanings.sent5: The ancient civilization used a special technique to carbonize wood for building structures.

meanings.definition: To char or burn (organic matter) so as to leave a carbon residue.
meanings.sent1: The campfire was so hot that it started to carbonize the marshmallows on the sticks.
meanings.sent2: The blacksmith would carefully carbonize the metal to create intricate designs.
meanings.sent3: The clumsy chef managed to carbonize the entire pot of soup, much to the amusement of the restaurant staff.
meanings.sent4: The wildfire had the power to carbonize entire forests, leaving behind only ash and charcoal.
meanings.sent5: The volcanic eruption was so intense that it could carbonize anything in its path within seconds.

meanings.definition: To subject (organic matter) to destructive distillation.
meanings.sent1: The ancient alchemists would carbonize various substances in their experiments.
meanings.sent2: The factory used a special process to carbonize the raw materials before turning them into products.
meanings.sent3: The magician's trick involved a potion that would mysteriously carbonize objects placed inside.
meanings.sent4: The intense pressure and heat in the earth's core can slowly carbonize rocks over millions of years.
meanings.sent5: The artist used a unique technique to carbonize the canvas, creating a striking visual effect.
